Basic usage of the ‘psychinterpreter’ Package

Matthias Kloft

2025-11-02

Overview

This document demonstrates the functionality of the psychinterpreter package using the Big Five personality data from the psych package. The Big Five Inventory (BFI) is a widely-used personality assessment that measures five major dimensions of personality: Openness, Conscientiousness, Extraversion, Agreeableness, and Neuroticism.

We’ll test all major features of psychinterpreter including:

  • Basic factor analysis interpretation
  • Persistent chat sessions for efficient LLM usage
  • Export functionality across multiple formats
  • Advanced interpretation features

Setup and Data Preparation 

library(psychinterpreter)
library(ellmer)
library(psych)
library(dplyr)
library(here)
library(pander)

# Load the BFI dataset and dictionary
data("bfi")
data("bfi.dictionary")

Preparing the BFI Data

Exclude demographic variables for factor analysis

bfi <- bfi[,1:25]
bfi.dictionary <- bfi.dictionary[1:25, ]
# Show the first few rows
head(bfi)
# Display the BFI dictionary showing item descriptions and keying
print(bfi.dictionary |> select(Item))
                                        Item
A1 Am indifferent to the feelings of others.
A2         Inquire about others' well-being.
A3               Know how to comfort others.
A4                            Love children.
A5                 Make people feel at ease.
C1                   Am exacting in my work.
C2     Continue until everything is perfect.
C3            Do things according to a plan.
C4           Do things in a half-way manner.
C5                            Waste my time.
E1                         Don't talk a lot.
E2     Find it difficult to approach others.
E3             Know how to captivate people.
E4                      Make friends easily.
E5                              Take charge.
N1                         Get angry easily.
N2                     Get irritated easily.
N3                Have frequent mood swings.
N4                          Often feel blue.
N5                             Panic easily.
O1                         Am full of ideas.
O2         Avoid difficult reading material.
O3 Carry the conversation to a higher level.
O4          Spend time reflecting on things.
O5     Will not probe deeply into a subject.

Factor Analysis

Determining Number of Factors 

# Parallel analysis to determine optimal number of factors
pa_result <- fa.parallel(
  bfi,
  fa = "fa",
  n.iter = 100,
  use = "pairwise.complete.obs",
  main = "Parallel Analysis: BFI Data"
)
Parallel analysis suggests that the number of factors =  6  and the number of components =  NA

Performing Exploratory Factor Analysis with 7 Factors

Perform FA with 7 factors identified by the parallel analysis

fa_result <- fa(
  bfi,
  nfactors = pa_result$nfact,
  rotate = "oblimin",
  fm = "ml"
)
# Extract loading matrix for interpretation
loadings_matrix <- unclass(fa_result$loadings) |> as.data.frame()
round(loadings_matrix, 2)
# Extract factor correlation matrix
factor_cor_mat <- fa_result$Phi |> as.data.frame()
round(factor_cor_mat, 2)

Interpreting Factor Analysis Results

Create variable information dataframe from BFI dictionary

variable_info <- data.frame(
  variable = rownames(bfi.dictionary),
  description = bfi.dictionary$Item,
  stringsAsFactors = FALSE
)

head(variable_info, 10)

Set up persistent chat session

chat <- chat_fa(
  provider = "ollama",
  model = "gpt-oss:20b-cloud",
  # set temperature and seed for reproducibility
  params = params(temperature = 0, seed = 42)
)

print(chat)

We now generate factor interpretations using the specified LLM:

result <- interpret_fa(
    loadings = loadings_matrix,
  variable_info = variable_info,
  cutoff = 0.3,
  n_emergency = 2,
  additional_info = NULL,
  factor_cor_mat = factor_cor_mat,
  sort_loadings = TRUE,
  suppress_small = TRUE,
  word_limit = 100,
  max_line_length = 80,
  silent = FALSE,
  echo = "none",
  output_format = "markdown",
  heading_level = 2,
  suppress_heading = TRUE,
  chat_session = chat
)

Number of factors: 6
Loading cutoff: 0.3

Detailed Factor Interpretations

Factor 1 (ML2):: Neuroticism

Number of significant loadings: 5 nVariance explained: 9.22% nFactor Correlations: ML1 = .25, ML3 = -0.18, ML5 = -0.10, nnML4 = .02, ML6 = .18

nnVariables:nn 1. N2, Get irritated easily. (Positive, Very Strong, .851) 2. N1, Get angry easily. (Positive, Very Strong, .851) 3. N3, Have frequent mood swings. (Positive, Strong, .639) 4. N5, Panic easily. (Positive, Moderate, .402) 5. N4, Often feel blue. (Positive, Weak, .389)

LLM Interpretation:
ML2 is dominated by the five neuroticism items (N1–N5), all loading above .39, with N1 and N2 exceeding .85. The strong positive loadings indicate that high scores reflect frequent negative affect, irritability, mood swings, sadness, and panic. Convergent validity is evident: all items measure facets of emotional instability, clustering tightly. The factor is distinct from the other constructs, as shown by low correlations with the extraversion, conscientiousness, agreeableness, and openness factors. Thus, ML2 captures a coherent neuroticism dimension in.

Factor 2 (ML1):: Social Inhibition

Number of significant loadings: 7 nVariance explained: 7.9% nFactor Correlations: ML2 = .25, ML3 = -0.22, ML5 = -0.31, nnML4 = -0.19, ML6 = -0.06

nnVariables:nn 1. E2, Find it difficult to approach others. (Positive, Strong, .686) 2. E1, Don’t talk a lot. (Positive, Strong, .587) 3. E4, Make friends easily. (Negative, Strong, -0.550) 4. N4, Often feel blue. (Positive, Moderate, .436) 5. E5, Take charge. (Negative, Moderate, -0.405) 6. O4, Spend time reflecting on things. (Positive, Weak, .355) 7. E3, Know how to captivate people. (Negative, Weak, -0.349)

LLM Interpretation:
ML1 is characterized by high loadings on E1 (talk a lot) and E2 (difficulty approaching others) and negative loadings on E3 (captivate), E4 (make friends), and E5 (take charge). The pattern suggests that individuals scoring high on this factor are socially engaged yet experience discomfort and lack of social skill, reflecting a social inhibition or introversion dimension. Convergent validity is supported by the clustering of social interaction items, while discriminant validity is evident from its modest correlations with the other factors, indicating a distinct construct.

Factor 3 (ML3):: Conscientiousness

Number of significant loadings: 5 nVariance explained: 7.71% nFactor Correlations: ML2 = -0.18, ML1 = -0.22, ML5 = .19, nnML4 = .19, ML6 = -0.03

nnVariables:nn 1. C2, Continue until everything is perfect. (Positive, Strong, .680) 2. C4, Do things in a half-way manner. (Negative, Strong, -0.634) 3. C3, Do things according to a plan. (Positive, Strong, .551) 4. C1, Am exacting in my work. (Positive, Strong, .547) 5. C5, Waste my time. (Negative, Strong, -0.541)

LLM Interpretation:
ML3 shows strong positive loadings on C1 (exacting), C2 (perfectionism), and C3 (planning), and strong negative loadings on C4 (half‑way) and C5 (waste time). This pattern captures the classic conscientiousness construct: high scores reflect orderliness, diligence, and goal orientation, whereas low scores indicate carelessness and procrastination. Convergent validity is evident as all items measure facets of self‑discipline. The factor is distinct from the other dimensions, with minimal correlations to neuroticism, extraversion, agreeableness, and openness, underscoring discriminant validity. This dimension is central to personality assessment.

Factor 4 (ML5):: Agreeableness

Number of significant loadings: 5 nVariance explained: 6.79% nFactor Correlations: ML2 = -0.10, ML1 = -0.31, ML3 = .19, nnML4 = .25, ML6 = .14

nnVariables:nn 1. A2, Inquire about others’ well-being. (Positive, Strong, .688) 2. A3, Know how to comfort others. (Positive, Strong, .617) 3. A1, Am indifferent to the feelings of others. (Negative, Strong, -0.560) 4. A5, Make people feel at ease. (Positive, Moderate, .451) 5. A4, Love children. (Positive, Weak, .391)

LLM Interpretation:
ML5 is defined by high loadings on A2 (inquire about others), A3 (comfort), A4 (love children), and A5 (make people feel at ease), with a strong negative loading on A1 (indifferent). These items collectively represent the agreeableness construct: warmth, empathy, and prosocial orientation versus callousness. Convergent validity is clear as all items tap interpersonal concern. The factor remains distinct from neuroticism, extraversion, conscientiousness, and openness, as indicated by low inter‑factor correlations, confirming discriminant validity. It is a core trait in social functioning.

Factor 5 (ML4):: Openness

Number of significant loadings: 6 nVariance explained: 6.27% nFactor Correlations: ML2 = .02, ML1 = -0.19, ML3 = .19, nnML5 = .25, ML6 = .02

nnVariables:nn 1. O3, Carry the conversation to a higher level. (Positive, Strong, .656) 2. O1, Am full of ideas. (Positive, Strong, .564) 3. O5, Will not probe deeply into a subject. (Negative, Moderate, -0.451) 4. E3, Know how to captivate people. (Positive, Weak, .392) 5. O4, Spend time reflecting on things. (Positive, Weak, .376) 6. O2, Avoid difficult reading material. (Negative, Weak, -0.367)

LLM Interpretation:
ML4 is characterized by strong positive loadings on O1 (full of ideas), O3 (carry conversation higher), and O4 (reflect), and negative loadings on O2 (avoid difficult reading) and O5 (not probe deeply). The pattern captures the openness to experience construct: imaginative, reflective, and intellectually curious versus conventional and superficial. Convergent validity is evident as all items measure facets of intellectual curiosity. The factor is distinct from the other dimensions, with low correlations to neuroticism, extraversion, conscientiousness, and agreeableness, supporting discriminant validity.

Factor 6 (ML6):: Impulsive Extraversion

Number of significant loadings: 2 nVariance explained: 3.12% nFactor Correlations: ML2 = .18, ML1 = -0.06, ML3 = -0.03, nnML5 = .14, ML4 = .02

nnVariables:nn 1. O5, Will not probe deeply into a subject. (Positive, Moderate, .403) 2. O2, Avoid difficult reading material. (Positive, Weak, .353)

LLM Interpretation:
ML6 shows moderate loadings on C4 (half‑way), O2 (avoid difficult reading), O5 (not probe deeply), E4 (make friends easily), and A5 (make people feel at ease). These items reflect a tendency toward low conscientiousness, superficial engagement, and social ease, suggesting an impulsive extraversion dimension. Convergent validity is supported by the clustering of items that capture spontaneous, socially oriented behavior. The factor remains distinct from the core personality dimensions, as indicated by its weak correlations with neuroticism, conscientiousness, agreeableness, and openness, confirming discriminant validity.

Cross-Loading Variables

Variables loading on multiple factors (>= 0.3):

  • E3: Know how to captivate people.: ML1 (-0.349), ML4 (.392)
  • N4: Often feel blue.: ML2 (.389), ML1 (.436)
  • O2: Avoid difficult reading material.: ML4 (-0.367), ML6 (.353)
  • O4: Spend time reflecting on things.: ML1 (.355), ML4 (.376)
  • O5: Will not probe deeply into a subject.: ML4 (-0.451), ML6 (.403)

Let’s check the global token usage tracked by the chat:

print(chat)
result$chat
<Chat Ollama/gpt-oss:20b-cloud turns=3 tokens=2078/5448>
── system [0] ──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
# ROLE
You are an expert psychometrician specializing in factor analysis.

# TASK
Provide comprehensive factor analysis interpretation by: (1) identifying and naming meaningful constructs, (2) explaining factor composition and boundaries, and (3) analyzing relationships between factors.

# KEY DEFINITIONS
- **Loading**: Correlation coefficient (-1 to +1) between variable and factor
- **Significant loading**: Loading with absolute value >= cutoff threshold
- **Convergent validity**: Variables measuring similar constructs should load together; for two factors covering similar constructs, the correlation will be highly positive or negative
- **Discriminant validity**: Factors should represent meaningfully distinct constructs; for two factors covering similar constructs, the correlation will be near zero
- **Factor correlation**: Correlation between factors indicating relationship strength
- **Factor interpretation**: Identifying underlying construct explaining variable relationships
- **Variance explained**: Percentage of total data variance captured by each factor
- **Emergency rule**: Use highest absolute loadings when none meet cutoff


── user [2078] ─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
# INTERPRETATION GUIDELINES

## Factor Naming
- **Construct identification**: Identify the underlying construct each factor represents
- **Name creation**: Create 2-4 word names capturing the essence of each factor
- **Theoretical grounding**: Base names on domain knowledge and additional context

## Factor Interpretation
- **Convergent validity**: Explain why significantly loading variables belong together conceptually
- **Loading patterns**: Examine both strong positive/negative loadings and notable weak loadings
- **Construct meaning**: Describe what the factor measures and represents
- **Factor Relationships**: Use correlation matrix and cross loadings to understand how factors relate to each other
- **Discriminant validity**: Ensure factors represent meaningfully distinct constructs; explain how similar factors complement each other

## Output Requirements
- **Word target (Interpretation)**: Aim for 80-100 words per interpretation (80%-100% of limit)
- **Writing style**: Be concise, precise, and domain-appropriate

# VARIABLE DESCRIPTIONS

```json
    "name": "Generate name",

    "name": "Generate name",
    "interpretation": "Generate interpretation"
  }
}
```

# CRITICAL REQUIREMENTS
- Include ALL 6 factors as object keys
- Use exact factor names as keys: ML2, ML1, ML3, ML5, ML4, ML6
- Valid JSON syntax (proper quotes, commas, brackets)
- No additional text before or after JSON
- Factor names: 2-4 words maximum
- Interpretations: 1-4 sentences, target 80-100 words each (80%-100% of 100 word limit)
- Apply convergent validity: Explain why variables load together
- Consider discriminant validity: Ensure factors represent distinct constructs
- Emergency rule: Use top 2 variables if no significant loadings

Plot the loading matrix with factor names:

plot(result)

Factor Analysis and Interpretation Using 5 Factors

Let’s repeat the interpretation with the theoretical number of 5 factors

fa_result_5f <- fa(
  bfi,
  nfactors = 5,
  rotate = "oblimin",
  fm = "ml",
  scores = TRUE
)

result <- interpret_fa(
    loadings = fa_result_5f$loadings,
  variable_info = variable_info,
  cutoff = 0.3,
  n_emergency = 2,
  additional_info = NULL,
  factor_cor_mat = factor_cor_mat,
  sort_loadings = TRUE,
  suppress_small = TRUE,
  word_limit = 100,
  max_line_length = 80,
  silent = FALSE,
  echo = "none",
  output_format = "markdown",
  heading_level = 2,
  suppress_heading = TRUE,
  chat_session = chat
)

Loading cutoff: 0.3

Output: 2929
Elapsed time: 13.8 secs

  • Factor 2 (7.7%): Agreeableness
  • Factor 3 (7.4%): Social Inhibition
  • Factor 4 (7.7%): Conscientiousness
  • Factor 5 (6.3%): Openness

    ML5 = .14, ML4 = .02

Detailed Factor Interpretations

Factor 1 (ML2):: Neuroticism

Number of significant loadings: 5 nVariance explained: 9.65% nFactor Correlations: ML1 = .25, ML3 = -0.18, ML5 = -0.10, nnML4 = .02, ML6 = .18

nnVariables:nn 1. N1, Get angry easily. (Positive, Very Strong, .852) 2. N2, Get irritated easily. (Positive, Very Strong, .817) 3. N3, Have frequent mood swings. (Positive, Strong, .665) 4. N5, Panic easily. (Positive, Moderate, .439) 5. N4, Often feel blue. (Positive, Moderate, .413)

LLM Interpretation:
ML2 is dominated by the five neuroticism items (N1–N5), all loading above .39, with N1 and N2 exceeding .85. The strong positive loadings indicate that high scores reflect frequent negative affect, irritability, mood swings, sadness, and panic. Convergent validity is evident: all items measure facets of emotional instability, clustering tightly. The factor is distinct from the other constructs, as shown by low correlations with the extraversion, conscientiousness, agreeableness, and openness factors. Thus, ML2 captures a coherent neuroticism dimension.

Factor 2 (ML5):: Agreeableness

Number of significant loadings: 7 nVariance explained: 7.69% nFactor Correlations: ML2 = -0.10, ML1 = -0.31, ML3 = .19, nnML4 = .25, ML6 = .14

nnVariables:nn 1. A3, Know how to comfort others. (Positive, Strong, .668) 2. A2, Inquire about others’ well-being. (Positive, Strong, .603) 3. A5, Make people feel at ease. (Positive, Strong, .577) 4. A4, Love children. (Positive, Moderate, .456) 5. E4, Make friends easily. (Positive, Weak, .362) 6. A1, Am indifferent to the feelings of others. (Negative, Weak, -0.360) 7. E3, Know how to captivate people. (Positive, Weak, .303)

LLM Interpretation:
ML5 is defined by high loadings on A2 (inquire about others), A3 (comfort), A4 (love children), and A5 (make people feel at ease), with a strong negative loading on A1 (indifferent). These items collectively represent the agreeableness construct: warmth, empathy, and prosocial orientation versus callousness. Convergent validity is clear as all items tap interpersonal concern. The factor remains distinct from neuroticism, extraversion, conscientiousness, and openness, as indicated by low inter‑factor correlations, confirming discriminant validity. It is a core trait in social functioning.

Factor 3 (ML1):: Social Inhibition

Number of significant loadings: 7 nVariance explained: 7.36% nFactor Correlations: ML2 = .25, ML3 = -0.22, ML5 = -0.31, nnML4 = -0.19, ML6 = -0.06

nnVariables:nn 1. E2, Find it difficult to approach others. (Positive, Strong, .667) 2. E1, Don’t talk a lot. (Positive, Strong, .565) 3. E4, Make friends easily. (Negative, Strong, -0.527) 4. N4, Often feel blue. (Positive, Moderate, .420) 5. E5, Take charge. (Negative, Weak, -0.394) 6. O4, Spend time reflecting on things. (Positive, Weak, .357) 7. E3, Know how to captivate people. (Negative, Weak, -0.341)

LLM Interpretation:
ML1 is dominated by the extraversion items E1 (don’t talk a lot) and E2 (find it difficult to approach others), with strong negative loadings on E3 (captivate), E4 (make friends easily), and E5 (take charge). The pattern indicates a social inhibition or introversion dimension: high scores reflect low talkativeness, social discomfort, and lack of assertiveness, while low scores denote outgoing, charismatic, and dominant behavior. Convergent validity is supported by the clustering of social interaction items, and discriminant validity is evident from its modest correlations with the other factors, underscoring a distinct construct.

Factor 4 (ML3):: Conscientiousness

Number of significant loadings: 5 nVariance explained: 7.71% nFactor Correlations: ML2 = -0.18, ML1 = -0.22, ML5 = .19, nnML4 = .19, ML6 = -0.03

nnVariables:nn 1. C4, Do things in a half-way manner. (Negative, Strong, -0.643) 2. C2, Continue until everything is perfect. (Positive, Strong, .638) 3. C5, Waste my time. (Negative, Strong, -0.570) 4. C3, Do things according to a plan. (Positive, Strong, .564) 5. C1, Am exacting in my work. (Positive, Strong, .532)

LLM Interpretation:
ML3 is characterized by strong positive loadings on C1 (exacting), C2 (perfectionism), and C3 (planning), and strong negative loadings on C4 (half‑way) and C5 (waste time). This pattern captures the conscientiousness construct: high scores reflect orderliness, diligence, and goal orientation, whereas low scores indicate carelessness and procrastination. Convergent validity is evident as all items measure facets of self‑discipline. The factor is distinct from the other dimensions, with minimal correlations to neuroticism, extraversion, agreeableness, and openness, underscoring discriminant validity. It is central to personality assessment.

Factor 5 (ML4):: Openness

Number of significant loadings: 6 nVariance explained: 6.25% nFactor Correlations: ML2 = .02, ML1 = -0.19, ML3 = .19, nnML5 = .25, ML6 = .02

nnVariables:nn 1. O3, Carry the conversation to a higher level. (Positive, Strong, .633) 2. O1, Am full of ideas. (Positive, Strong, .534) 3. O5, Will not probe deeply into a subject. (Negative, Strong, -0.522) 4. O2, Avoid difficult reading material. (Negative, Moderate, -0.441) 5. O4, Spend time reflecting on things. (Positive, Weak, .379) 6. E3, Know how to captivate people. (Positive, Weak, .315)

LLM Interpretation:
ML4 is defined by high loadings on O1 (full of ideas), O3 (carry conversation higher), and O4 (reflect), with negative loadings on O2 (avoid difficult reading) and O5 (not probe deeply). These items capture the openness to experience construct: imaginative, reflective, and intellectually curious versus conventional and superficial. Convergent validity is clear as all items tap intellectual curiosity. The factor remains distinct from neuroticism, extraversion, conscientiousness, and agreeableness, as indicated by low inter‑factor correlations, confirming discriminant validity. It represents a core dimension of creative and reflective thinking.

Cross-Loading Variables

Variables loading on multiple factors (>= 0.3):

  • E3: Know how to captivate people.: ML5 (.303), ML1 (-0.341), ML4 (.315)
  • E4: Make friends easily.: ML5 (.362), ML1 (-0.527)
  • N4: Often feel blue.: ML2 (.413), ML1 (.420)
  • O4: Spend time reflecting on things.: ML1 (.357), ML4 (.379)

We can again check the total global token usage:

print(chat)

Export Functionality

We can export the results to multiple formats

# CSV export
export_interpretation(result,
                      format = "csv",
                      file = here("exports", "bfi_analysis.csv"))

# JSON export
export_interpretation(result,
                      format = "json",
                      file = here("exports", "bfi_analysis.json"))

# RDS export
export_interpretation(result,
                      format = "rds",
                      file = here("exports", "bfi_analysis.rds"))

# TXT export
export_interpretation(result,
                      format = "txt",
                      file = here("exports", "bfi_analysis.txt"))
